sub_title: MSc student Behavioural Ecology at Utrecht University
summary:
I am currently a Master student in Environmental Biology with specialisation track Behavioural Ecology at Utrecht University. During my Master's, I focus on the behaviour of primates in relation to welfare and on science communication. 

Currently, I am conducting research into the effects of maternal loss and siblinghood on the social and vocal behaviour of rhesus macaques (Macaca mulatta) at the Biomedical Primate Research Centre Rijswijk (BPRC). In September I will start my communication profile as final component of my Master's during which I will gain further knowledge and experience in science communication. In September I will therefore also start with my internship at NEMO Kennislink during which I will gain more experience in the field of science journalism.

In the future I hope to communicate the importance of animal welfare and the conservation of animal species to the general public and hopefully help to make a contribution to its developments.

projects:
[{'title': "Hidden Biodiversity: 'Stadssafari'", 'date': {'start': {'month': 4, 'day': None, 'year': 2023}, 'end': {'month': 6, 'day': None, 'year': 2023}}, 'description': "In ten weeks, I developed a public engagement activity for the 'Hidden Biodiversity' project of Naturalis Biodiversity Center. For this, I collaborated with Amy van Nobelen (Science Communication officer for Naturalis Biodiversity Center).

The ‘Hidden Biodiversity’ project focusses on educating the general public about the hidden biodiversity in cities such as fungi, bacteria, soil animals, mosses and lichens. Simultaneously, Naturalis aims to collect a database of all biodiversity in cities through ObsIdenitfy and find out its effect (e.g. does it help make cities more climate resistant?). 
 
I focused on the first steps of the ‘Hidden Biodiversity’ project and designed a plan for a public engagement activity to educate the general public about the hidden biodiversity in cities. I therefore designed a 'Stadssafari' (a safari through the city of Leiden). The aims of this activity are firstly to educate the public on the importance and benefits of mosses and lichens. Secondly, we want to change the public’s attitude regarding these organisms. Additionally, we want to teach and motivate participants to use ObsIdentify, and, finally, I want to provide Naturalis with insight in the knowledge and attitude of the public regarding hidden biodiversity. By meeting these aims during the 'Stadssafari', citizens will hopefully be more inclined to appreciate and give space to the hidden biodiversity in their surroundings, which will, in turn, result in a greener and more climate resistant city.", 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Bernadette', 'last_name': 'Bruinstroop', 'name': None, 'headline': 'MSc student Behavioural Ecology at Utrecht University'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Amy', 'last_name': 'van Nobelen', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Medewerker wetenschapscommunicatie bij Naturalis Biodiversity Center Nederland'}]}]
